results.name: T(n,k) is the number of weak compositions of k into n parts no greater than (n-1) for n>=1, 0<=k<=n(n-1).
comment: T(n,k) is the number of length n sequences on an alphabet of {0,1,2,...,n-1} that have a sum of k. Equivalently T(n,k) is the number of functions f:{1,2,...,n}->{0,1,2,...,n-1} such that Sum(f(i)=k, i=1...n).
Row n is also row n of the array of q-nomial coefficients. - _Matthew Vandermast_, Oct 31 2010
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 1..32, flattened
formula: O.g.f. for row n is ((1-x^n)/(1-x))^n. For k<=(n-1), T(n,k) = C(n+k-1,k).
example: T(3,4) = 6 because there are 6 ternary sequences of length three that sum to 4: [0, 2, 2], [1, 1, 2], [1, 2, 1], [2, 0, 2], [2, 1, 1], [2, 2, 0].
maple: b:= proc(n, k, l) option remember; `if`(k=0, 1,
seq(seq(T(n, k), k=0..n*(n-1)), n=1..8);  # _Alois P. Heinz_, Feb 21 2013
xref: The maximum of row n is in column k=n(n-1)/2 = A000217(n-1).
For q-nomial arrays, see A000012, A007318, A027907, A008287, A035343, A063260, A063265, A171890. See also A181567. - _Matthew Vandermast_, Oct 31 2010
